Redundancy-Related Bounds for Generalized Huffman Codes

Michael B. Baer,  Material in this paper was presented at the 2006 International Symposium on Information Theory, Seattle, Washington, USA and the 2008 International Symposium on Information Theory, Toronto, Ontario, Canada.The author is with Vista Research, 4 Lower Ragsdale Drive, Suite 220, Monterey, California 93940 USA (email: calbear@ieee.org).This work has been submitted to the IEEE for possible publication. Copyright may be transferred without notice, after which this version may no longer be accessible.
Abstract

This paper presents new lower and upper bounds for the compression rate of binary prefix codes optimized over memoryless sources according to various nonlinear codeword length objectives. Like the most well-known redundancy bounds for minimum average redundancy coding — Huffman coding — these are in terms of a form of entropy and/or the probability of an input symbol, often the most probable one. The bounds here, some of which are tight, improve on known bounds of the form L∈[H,H+1)𝐿𝐻𝐻1L\in[H,H+1)italic_L ∈ [ italic_H , italic_H + 1 ), where H𝐻Hitalic_H is some form of entropy in bits (or, in the case of redundancy objectives, 00) and L𝐿Litalic_L is the length objective, also in bits. The objectives explored here include exponential-average length, maximum pointwise redundancy, and exponential-average pointwise redundancy (also called d𝑑ditalic_dth exponential redundancy). The first of these relates to various problems involving queueing, uncertainty, and lossless communications; the second relates to problems involving Shannon coding and universal modeling. For these two objectives we also explore the related problem of the necessary and sufficient conditions for the shortest codeword of a code being a specific length.exponential redundancy). The first of these relates to various problems involving queueing, uncertainty, and lossless communications; the second relates to problems involving Shannon coding and universal modeling. For these two objectives we also explore the related problem of the necessary and sufficient conditions for the shortest codeword of a code being a specific length.

Huffman codes, optimal prefix code, queueing, Rényi entropy, Shannon codes, worst case minimax redundancy.

I Introduction

Since Shannon introduced information theory, we have had entropy bounds for the expected codeword length of optimal lossless fixed-to-variable-length binary codes. The lower bound is entropy, while the upper bound is one bit greater — corresponding to a maximum average redundancy of one bit for an optimal code — thus yielding unit-sized bounds. The upper bound follows from the suboptimal Shannon code, a code for which the codeword length of an input of probability p𝑝pitalic_p is ⌈-log2⁡p⌉subscript2𝑝\lceil-\log_{2}p\rceil⌈ - roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ⌉[1].

Huffman found a method of producing an optimal code by building a tree in which the two nodes with lowest weight (probability) are merged to produce a node with their combined weight summed[2]. On the occasion of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Huffman algorithm, Gallager introduced bounds in terms of the most probable symbol which improved on the unit-sized redundancy bound[3]. Since then, improvements in both upper and lower bounds given this most probable symbol[4, 5, 6, 7, 8] have yielded bounds that are tight when this symbol’s probability is at least 1/12711271/1271 / 127 (and close-to-tight when it has lower probability). Tight bounds also exist for upper and lower bounds given the less-specific information of an arbitrary symbol’s probability[9, 10]. Such bounds are useful for quickly bounding the performance of an optimal code without running the algorithm that would produce the code. The bounds are for a fixed-sized input alphabet; asymptotic treatment of redundancy for block codes of growing size, based on binary memoryless sources, is given in [11].

Others have given consideration to objectives other than expected codeword length[12, §2.6]. Many of these nonlinear objectives, which have a variety of applications, also have unit-sized bounds but have heretofore lacked tighter closed-form bounds achieved using a symbol probability and, if necessary, some form of entropy. We address such problems here, finding upper and lower bounds for the optimal codes of given probability mass functions for nonlinear objectives. “Optimal” in this paper refers to optimality over the objective in question, not necessarily over the linear objective of expectation.

A prefix code — also referred to as a comma-free code, a prefix-free code, or an instantaneous code — is a code for which no codeword begins with a sequence that also comprises the whole of a second codeword.

This problem is equivalent to finding a minimum-weight external path among all rooted binary trees, due to the fact that every prefix code can be represented as a binary tree. In this tree representation, each edge from a parent node to a child node is labeled 00 (left) or 1111 (right), with at most one of each type of edge per parent node. A leaf is a node without children; this corresponds to a codeword, and the codeword is determined by the path from the root to the leaf. Thus, for example, a leaf that is the right-edge (1111) child of a left-edge (00) child of a left-edge (00) child of the root will correspond to codeword 001001001001. Leaf depth (distance from the root) is thus codeword length. If we represent external path weight as ∑i∈𝒳w⁢(i)⁢lisubscript𝑖𝒳𝑤𝑖subscript𝑙𝑖\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{X}}}w(i)l_{i}∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ caligraphic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w ( italic_i ) italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the weights are the probabilities (i.e., w⁢(i)=pi𝑤𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖w(i)=p_{i}italic_w ( italic_i ) = italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), and, in fact, we refer to the problem inputs as {w⁢(i)}𝑤𝑖\{w(i)\}{ italic_w ( italic_i ) } for certain generalizations in which their sum, ∑i∈𝒳w⁢(i)subscript𝑖𝒳𝑤𝑖\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{X}}}w(i)∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ caligraphic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w ( italic_i ), need not be 1111.

Because Huffman’s algorithm[2] finds codes minimizing average redundancy (1), the minimum-average redundancy problem itself is often referred to as the “Huffman problem,” even though the problem did not originate with Huffman himself. Huffman’s algorithm is a greedy algorithm built on the observation that the two least likely items will have the same length and can thus be considered siblings in the coding tree. A reduction is thus made in which the two items of weights w⁢(i)𝑤𝑖w(i)italic_w ( italic_i ) and w⁢(j)𝑤𝑗w(j)italic_w ( italic_j ) are considered as one with combined weight w⁢(i)+w⁢(j)𝑤𝑖𝑤𝑗w(i)+w(j)italic_w ( italic_i ) + italic_w ( italic_j ). The codeword of the combined item determines all but the last bit of each of the items combined, which are differentiated by this last bit. This reduction continues until there is one item left, and, assigning this item the null string, a code is defined for all input items. In the corresponding optimal code tree, the i𝑖iitalic_ith leaf corresponds to the codeword of the i𝑖iitalic_ith input item, and thus has weight w⁢(i)𝑤𝑖w(i)italic_w ( italic_i ), whereas the weight of parent nodes are determined by the combined weight of the corresponding merged item.

in the case of other length objectives.

All of the nonlinear objectives we consider have been shown to be solved by generalized versions of the Huffman algorithm[14, 15, 16, 17, 18]. These generalizations change the combining rule; instead of replacing items i𝑖iitalic_i and j𝑗jitalic_j with an item of weight w⁢(i)+w⁢(j)𝑤𝑖𝑤𝑗w(i)+w(j)italic_w ( italic_i ) + italic_w ( italic_j ), the generalized algorithm replaces them with an item of weight f⁢(w⁢(i),w⁢(j))𝑓𝑤𝑖𝑤𝑗f(w(i),w(j))italic_f ( italic_w ( italic_i ) , italic_w ( italic_j ) ) for some function f𝑓fitalic_f. The weight of a combined item (a node) therefore need not be equal to the sum of the probabilities of the items merged to create it (the sum of the leaves of the corresponding subtree). Thus the sum of weights in a reduced problem need not be 1111, unlike in the original Huffman algorithm. In particular, the weight of the root, wrootsubscript𝑤rootw_{\mathop{\rm root}}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_root end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, need not be 1111. However, we continue to assume that the sum of inputs to the coding problems will be 1111 (with the exception of reductions among problems).

The next section introduces the objectives of interest, along with their motivations and our main contributions. These contributions, indicated by ( ☞ ), are bounds on performance of optimal codes according to their optimizing objectives, as well as related properties. We defer the formal presentation of these contributions, along with proofs, until later sections, where they are presented as theorems and corollaries, along with the remarks immediately following them and associated figures. These begin in Section III, where we find tight exhaustive bounds for the values of minimized maximum pointwise redundancy (2) and corresponding ljsubscript𝑙𝑗l_{j}italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in terms of pjsubscript𝑝𝑗p_{j}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Pointwise redundancy for a symbol i𝑖iitalic_i is li+lg⁡pisubscript𝑙𝑖lgsubscript𝑝𝑖l_{i}+\lg p_{i}italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + roman_lg italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In Section IV, we then extend these to exhaustive — but not tight — bounds for minimized d𝑑ditalic_dth exponential redundancy (4), a measure which takes a β𝛽\betaitalic_β-exponential average[19] of pointwise redundancy (where, in this case, parameter β𝛽\betaitalic_β is d𝑑ditalic_d). In Section V, we investigate the behavior of codes with minimized exponential average (6), including bounds and optimizing l1subscript𝑙1l_{1}italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in terms of p1subscript𝑝1p_{1}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

II Objectives, Motivations, and Main Results

II-A Maximum pointwise redundancy (R*superscript𝑅R^{*}italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT)

The most recently proposed problem objective we consider is that formulated by Drmota and Szpankowski[20]. Instead of minimizing average redundancy R¯⁢(𝒍,𝒑)≜∑i∈𝒳pi⁢(li+lg⁡pi)≜¯𝑅𝒍𝒑subscript𝑖𝒳subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑙𝑖lgsubscript𝑝𝑖\bar{R}({\mbox{\boldmath$l$}},{\mbox{\boldmath$p$}})\triangleq\sum_{i\in{% \mathcal{X}}}p_{i}(l_{i}+\lg p_{i})¯ start_ARG italic_R end_ARG ( bold_italic_l , bold_italic_p ) ≜ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ caligraphic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + roman_lg italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), here we minimize maximum pointwise redundancy

R*⁢(𝒍,𝒑)≜maxi∈𝒳⁡(li+lg⁡pi).≜superscript𝑅𝒍𝒑subscript𝑖𝒳subscript𝑙𝑖lgsubscript𝑝𝑖R^{*}({\mbox{\boldmath$l$}},{\mbox{\boldmath$p$}})\triangleq\max_{i\in{% \mathcal{X}}}(l_{i}+\lg p_{i}).italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_l , bold_italic_p ) ≜ roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ caligraphic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + roman_lg italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (2)

An extension of Shannon coding introduced by Blumer and McEliece[21, p. 1244] to upper-bound the problem considered in Section II-C was later rediscovered and efficiently implemented by Drmota and Szpankowski as a solution to this maximum pointwise redundancy problem. A subsequent solution to the problem is a variation of Huffman coding[18] derived from that in [22], one using combining rule

f*⁢(w⁢(i),w⁢(j))≜2⁢max⁡(w⁢(i),w⁢(j)).≜superscript𝑓𝑤𝑖𝑤𝑗2𝑤𝑖𝑤𝑗f^{*}(w(i),w(j))\triangleq 2\max(w(i),w(j)).italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_w ( italic_i ) , italic_w ( italic_j ) ) ≜ 2 roman_max ( italic_w ( italic_i ) , italic_w ( italic_j ) ) . (3)

Applications in prior literature

The solution of this worst-case pointwise redundancy problem is relevant to optimizing maximal (worst-case) minimax redundancy, a universal modeling problem (as in [23, p. 176]) for which the set 𝒫𝒫{\mathcal{P}}caligraphic_P of possible probability distributions results in a normalized “maximum likelihood distribution.”[20] More recently Gawrychowski and Gagie proposed a second worst-case redundancy problem which also finds its solution in minimizing maximum pointwise redundancy[24]. For this problem, normalization is not relevant and one allows any probability distribution that is consistent with an empirical distribution based on sampling.

Prior and current results

The first proposed algorithm for the maximum pointwise redundancy problem is a codeword-wise improvement on the Shannon code in the sense that each codeword is the same length as or one bit shorter than the corresponding codeword in the Shannon code. This method is called “generalized Shannon coding.” (With proper tie-breaking techniques, the Huffman-like solution guarantees that each codeword, in turn, is no longer than the generalized Shannon codeword. As both methods guarantee optimality, this makes no difference in the maximum pointwise redundancy.) Notice a property true of Shannon codes — generalized or not — but not minimum average redundancy (Huffman) codes: Because any given codeword has a length lisubscript𝑙𝑖l_{i}italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT not exceeding ⌈-lg⁡pi⌉lgsubscript𝑝𝑖\lceil-\lg p_{i}\rceil⌈ - roman_lg italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⌉, this length is within one bit of the associated input symbol’s self-information, -lg⁡pilgsubscript𝑝𝑖-\lg p_{i}- roman_lg italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This results in bounds of Ropt*⁢(𝒑)∈[0,1)superscriptsubscript𝑅opt𝒑01R_{\mathop{\rm opt}}^{*}({\mbox{\boldmath$p$}})\in[0,1)italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_opt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_p ) ∈ [ 0 , 1 ), which are improved upon in Section III. The bound can also be considered a degenerative case from a result of Shtarkov [23, p. 176], that for which the probabilities are fully known.

The aforementioned papers contain further analysis of this problem, but no improved closed-form bounds of the type introduced here. Here results are given as strict upper and lower bounds in Theorem 1 in Section III-A. Prior and current results and applications

This redundancy objective is less analyzed than the others mentioned here, likely because there are no direct applications in the published literature. However, it is closely related not only to average redundancy and to maximum pointwise redundancy, but also to the more applicable objective considered in Section II-C. Solution properties of these objectives — including redundancy bounds — can therefore be related via d𝑑ditalic_dth exponential redundancy. In particular, as we show in Section IV, the upper bound for maximum pointwise redundancy also improves upon the already-known bound for d𝑑ditalic_dth exponential redundancy,

Applications (a<1𝑎1a<1italic_a < 1)

It is important to note here that a>1𝑎1a>1italic_a > 1 is an average of growing exponentials, while a<1𝑎1a<1italic_a < 1 is an average of decaying exponentials. These two subproblems have different properties and have often been considered separately in the literature. An application for the decaying exponential variant involving single-shot communications has a communication channel with a window of opportunity of a total duration (in bits) distributed geometrically with parameter a𝑎aitalic_a [29]. Applications (a>1𝑎1a>1italic_a > 1)

We add an additional observation on a modified version of this problem: Suppose there are a sequence of windows of opportunities rather than only one. The probability that a window stays open long enough to send a message of length lisubscript𝑙𝑖l_{i}italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is alisuperscript𝑎subscript𝑙𝑖a^{l_{i}}italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, since each additional bit has independent probability a𝑎aitalic_a of getting through. Thus, given lisubscript𝑙𝑖l_{i}italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the expected number of windows needed to send a message — assuming it is necessary to resend communication for each window — is the multiplicative inverse of this. Overall expectation is therefore

𝔼⁢[N]=∑i=1npi⁢a-li=a-La-1⁢(𝒑,𝒍).𝔼delimited-[]𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑝𝑖superscript𝑎subscript𝑙𝑖superscript𝑎subscript𝐿superscript𝑎1𝒑𝒍{\mathbb{E}}[N]=\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}a^{-l_{i}}=a^{-L_{a^{-1}}({\mbox{% \scriptsize\boldmath$p$}},{\mbox{\scriptsize\boldmath$l$}})}.blackboard_E [ italic_N ] = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_p , bold_italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Although such a resending of communications is usually not needed for a constant message, this problem is a notable dual to the first problem. In this dual problem, we seek to minimize the expectation of a growing exponential of lengths rather than maximize the expectation of a decaying exponential.

Originally, the a>1𝑎1a>1italic_a > 1 variation of (6) was used in Humblet’s dissertation[30] for a queueing application originally proposed by Jelinek[31] and expounded upon in [21]. This problem is one in which overflow probability should be minimized, where the source produces symbols randomly and the codewords are temporarily stored in a finite buffer. In this problem, there exists an a>1𝑎1a>1italic_a > 1 such that optimizing La⁢(𝒑,𝒍)subscript𝐿𝑎𝒑𝒍L_{a}({\mbox{\boldmath$p$}},{\mbox{\boldmath$l$}})italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_p , bold_italic_l ) optimizes this problem; the correct a𝑎aitalic_a is found through iteration. The Huffman-like coding method was simultaneously published in [14, 15, 28]; in the last of these, Humblet noted that the Huffman combining method (7) finds the optimal code with a∈(0,1)𝑎01a\in(0,1)italic_a ∈ ( 0 , 1 ) as well.

More recently, the a>1𝑎1a>1italic_a > 1 variation was shown to have a third application[32]. In this problem, the true probability of the source is not known; it is only known that the relative entropy between the true probability and 𝒑𝒑pbold_italic_p is within some known bound. As in Humblet’s queueing problem, there is an a>1𝑎1a>1italic_a > 1, found via iteration, such that optimizing La⁢(𝒑,𝒍)subscript𝐿𝑎𝒑𝒍L_{a}({\mbox{\boldmath$p$}},{\mbox{\boldmath$l$}})italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_p , bold_italic_l ) solves the problem.

Prior and current results

Note that a→1→𝑎1a\rightarrow 1italic_a → 1 corresponds to the usual linear expectation objective. Problems for a𝑎aitalic_a near 1111 are of special interest, since a↓1↓𝑎1a\downarrow 1italic_a ↓ 1 corresponds to the minimum-variance solution if the problem has multiple solutions — as noted in [15], among others — while a↑1↑𝑎1a\uparrow 1italic_a ↑ 1 corresponds to the maximum-variance solution.

Most of the aforementioned improved bounds are based on a given highest symbol probability, p1subscript𝑝1p_{1}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We thus give this case special attention and also discuss the related property of the length of the most likely codeword in these coding problems. The bounds in this paper are the first of their kind for nontraditional Huffman codes, bounds which are, for Lasubscript𝐿𝑎L_{a}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, functions of both entropy and p1subscript𝑝1p_{1}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as in the traditional case. However, they are not the first improved bounds for such codes. More sophisticated bounds on the optimal solution for the exponential-average objective are given in [21] for a>1𝑎1a>1italic_a > 1; these appear as solutions to related problems rather than in closed form, however, and these problems require no less time or space to solve than the original problem. They are mainly useful for analysis. Bounds given elsewhere for a closely related objective having a one-to-one correspondence with (6) are demonstrated under the assumption that p1≥0.4subscript𝑝10.4p_{1}\geq 0.4italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0.4 always implies l1subscript𝑙1l_{1}italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be 1111 for the optimal code[33]. We show that this is not necessarily the case due to the difference between the exponential-average objective and the usual objective of an arithmetic average.

Specifically, Theorem 3 states that, for a∈(0.5,1]𝑎0.51a\in(0.5,1]italic_a ∈ ( 0.5 , 1 ], a code with shortest codeword of length 1111 is optimal if p1≥2⁢a/(2⁢a+3)subscript𝑝12𝑎2𝑎3p_{1}\geq 2a/(2a+3)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 2 italic_a / ( 2 italic_a + 3 ). Furthermore, for a>1𝑎1a>1italic_a > 1, no value of p1∈(0,1)subscript𝑝101p_{1}\in(0,1)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ ( 0 , 1 ) guarantees l1=1subscript𝑙11l_{1}=1italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1, and, for a≤0.5𝑎0.5a\leq 0.5italic_a ≤ 0.5, there is always an optimal code with l1=1subscript𝑙11l_{1}=1italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1, regardless of the input distribution. This results in the improved bounds of Corollary 3; when a∈(0.5,1)𝑎0.51a\in(0.5,1)italic_a ∈ ( 0.5 , 1 ) and p1≥2⁢a/(2⁢a+3)subscript𝑝12𝑎2𝑎3p_{1}\geq 2a/(2a+3)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 2 italic_a / ( 2 italic_a + 3 ), optimal 𝒍𝒍lbold_italic_l satisfies

A few observations can be used to find a series of improved lower and upper bounds on optimum maximum pointwise redundancy based on (9):

Properties, Maximum Pointwise Redundancy

Lemma 1

Suppose we apply (3) to find a Huffman-like code tree in order to minimize maximum pointwise redundancy (R¯⁢(𝐥,𝐩)normal-¯𝑅𝐥𝐩\bar{R}({\mbox{\boldmath$l$}},{\mbox{\boldmath$p$}})¯ start_ARG italic_R end_ARG ( bold_italic_l , bold_italic_p ) given 𝐩𝐩pbold_italic_p). Then the following holds:

  1. 1.

    Items are always merged by nondecreasing weight.

  2. 2.

    The weight of the root wrootsubscript𝑤rootw_{\mathop{\rm root}}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_root end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the coding tree determines the maximum pointwise redundancy, R*⁢(𝒍,𝒑)=lg⁡wrootsuperscript𝑅𝒍𝒑lgsubscript𝑤rootR^{*}({\mbox{\boldmath$l$}},{\mbox{\boldmath$p$}})=\lg w_{\mathop{\rm root}}italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_l , bold_italic_p ) = roman_lg italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_root end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  3. 3.

    The total probability of any subtree is no greater than the total weight of the subtree.

  4. 4.

    If p1≤2⁢pn-1subscript𝑝12subscript𝑝𝑛1p_{1}\leq 2p_{n-1}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ 2 italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then a minimum maximum pointwise redundancy code can be represented by a complete tree, that is, a tree with leaves at depth ⌊lg⁡n⌋lg𝑛\lfloor\lg n\rfloor⌊ roman_lg italic_n ⌋ and ⌈lg⁡n⌉lg𝑛\lceil\lg n\rceil⌈ roman_lg italic_n ⌉ only (with ∑i∈𝒳2-li=1subscript𝑖𝒳superscript2subscript𝑙𝑖1\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{X}}}2^{-l_{i}}=1∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ caligraphic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1). (This property is similar to the property noted in [34] for optimal-expected-length codes of sources termed quasi-uniform in [35].)

Proof:

We use an inductive proof in which base cases of sizes 1111 and 2222 are trivial, and we use weight function w𝑤witalic_w instead of probability mass function 𝒑𝒑pbold_italic_p to emphasize that the sums of weights need not necessarily add up to 1111. Assume first that all properties here are true for trees of size n-1𝑛1n-1italic_n - 1 and smaller. We wish to show that they are true for trees of size n𝑛nitalic_n.

The first property is true because f*⁢(w⁢(i),w⁢(j))=2⁢max⁡(w⁢(i),w⁢(j))>w⁢(i)superscript𝑓𝑤𝑖𝑤𝑗2𝑤𝑖𝑤𝑗𝑤𝑖f^{*}(w(i),w(j))=2\max(w(i),w(j))>w(i)italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_w ( italic_i ) , italic_w ( italic_j ) ) = 2 roman_max ( italic_w ( italic_i ) , italic_w ( italic_j ) ) > italic_w ( italic_i ) for any i𝑖iitalic_i and j𝑗jitalic_j; that is, a compound item always has greater weight than either of the items combined to form it. Thus, after the first two weights are combined, all remaining weights, including the compound weight, are no less than either of the two original weights.

This value is identical to that of the maximum redundancy, lg⁡1.2=lg⁡wrootlg1.2lgsubscript𝑤root\lg 1.2=\lg w_{\mathop{\rm root}}roman_lg 1.2 = roman_lg italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_root end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

For the third property, the first combined pair yields a weight that is no less than the combined probabilities. Thus, via induction, the total probability of any (sub)tree is no greater than the weight of the (sub)tree.

In order to show the final property, first note that ∑i∈𝒳2-li=1subscript𝑖𝒳superscript2subscript𝑙𝑖1\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{X}}}2^{-l_{i}}=1∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ caligraphic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 for any tree created using the Huffman-like procedure, since all internal nodes have two children. Now think of the procedure as starting with a (priority) queue of input items, ordered by nondecreasing weight from head to tail. After merging two items, obtained from the head of the queue, into one compound item, that item is placed back into the queue as one item, but not necessarily at the tail; an item is placed such that its weight is no smaller than any item ahead of it and is smaller than any item behind it. In keeping items ordered, this results in an optimal coding tree. A variant of this method can be used for linear-time coding[18].

In this case, we show not only that an optimal complete tree exists, but that, given an n𝑛nitalic_n-item tree, all items that finish at level ⌈lg⁡n⌉lg𝑛\lceil\lg n\rceil⌈ roman_lg italic_n ⌉ appear closer to the head of the queue than any item at level ⌈lg⁡n⌉-1lg𝑛1\lceil\lg n\rceil-1⌈ roman_lg italic_n ⌉ - 1 (if any), using a similar approach to the proof of Lemma 2 in [29]. Suppose this is true for every case with n-1𝑛1n-1italic_n - 1 items for n>2𝑛2n>2italic_n > 2, that is, that all nodes are at levels ⌊lg⁡(n-1)⌋lg𝑛1\lfloor\lg(n-1)\rfloor⌊ roman_lg ( italic_n - 1 ) ⌋ or ⌈lg⁡(n-1)⌉lg𝑛1\lceil\lg(n-1)\rceil⌈ roman_lg ( italic_n - 1 ) ⌉, with the latter items closer to the head of the queue than the former. Consider now a case with n𝑛nitalic_n nodes. The first step of coding is to merge two nodes, resulting in a combined item that is placed at the end of the combined-item queue, as we have asserted that p1≤2⁢pn-1=2⁢max⁡(pn-1,pn)subscript𝑝12subscript𝑝𝑛12subscript𝑝𝑛1subscript𝑝𝑛p_{1}\leq 2p_{n-1}=2\max(p_{n-1},p_{n})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ 2 italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 2 roman_max ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Because it is at the end of the queue in the n-1𝑛1n-1italic_n - 1 case, this combined node is at level ⌊lg⁡(n-1)⌋lg𝑛1\lfloor\lg(n-1)\rfloor⌊ roman_lg ( italic_n - 1 ) ⌋ in the final tree, and its children are at level 1+⌊lg⁡(n-1)⌋=⌈lg⁡n⌉1lg𝑛1lg𝑛1+\lfloor\lg(n-1)\rfloor=\lceil\lg n\rceil1 + ⌊ roman_lg ( italic_n - 1 ) ⌋ = ⌈ roman_lg italic_n ⌉. If n𝑛nitalic_n is a power of two, the remaining items end up on level lg⁡n=⌈lg⁡(n-1)⌉lg𝑛lg𝑛1\lg n=\lceil\lg(n-1)\rceilroman_lg italic_n = ⌈ roman_lg ( italic_n - 1 ) ⌉, satisfying this lemma. If n-1𝑛1n-1italic_n - 1 is a power of two, they end up on level lg⁡(n-1)=⌊lg⁡n⌋lg𝑛1lg𝑛\lg(n-1)=\lfloor\lg n\rfloorroman_lg ( italic_n - 1 ) = ⌊ roman_lg italic_n ⌋, also satisfying the lemma. Otherwise, there is at least one item ending up at level ⌈lg⁡n⌉=⌈lg⁡(n-1)⌉lg𝑛lg𝑛1\lceil\lg n\rceil=\lceil\lg(n-1)\rceil⌈ roman_lg italic_n ⌉ = ⌈ roman_lg ( italic_n - 1 ) ⌉ near the head of the queue, followed by the remaining items, which end up at level ⌊lg⁡n⌋=⌊lg⁡(n-1)⌋lg𝑛lg𝑛1\lfloor\lg n\rfloor=\lfloor\lg(n-1)\rfloor⌊ roman_lg italic_n ⌋ = ⌊ roman_lg ( italic_n - 1 ) ⌋. In any case, all properties of the lemma are satisfied for n𝑛nitalic_n items, and thus for any number of items. ∎

We can now present the improved redundancy bounds.

Approaching 1111, the upper and lower bounds on minimum average redundancy coding converge but never merge, whereas the minimum maximum redundancy bounds are identical for p1≥2/3subscript𝑝123p_{1}\geq 2/3italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 2 / 3.

III-B Minimized maximum pointwise redundancy codeword lengths

In addition to finding redundancy bounds in terms of p1subscript𝑝1p_{1}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or pjsubscript𝑝𝑗p_{j}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, it is also often useful to find bounds on the behavior of ljsubscript𝑙𝑗l_{j}italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in terms of pjsubscript𝑝𝑗p_{j}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (for j=1𝑗1j=1italic_j = 1 or general j𝑗jitalic_j), as was done for optimal average redundancy in [36] (for j=1𝑗1j=1italic_j = 1).

V Bounds on Exponential-Average Problems

V-A Previously known exponential-average bounds

While the average, maximum, and d𝑑ditalic_dth average redundancy problems yield performance bounds in terms of p1subscript𝑝1p_{1}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (or any pjsubscript𝑝𝑗p_{j}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) alone, here we seek to find any bounds on La⁢(𝒑,𝒍)subscript𝐿𝑎𝒑𝒍L_{a}({\mbox{\boldmath$p$}},{\mbox{\boldmath$l$}})italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_p , bold_italic_l ) in terms of p1subscript𝑝1p_{1}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and an appropriate entropy measure. Such a more general form is needed because, unlike the other objectives discussed here, this is not a redundancy objective.

Note that a≤0.5𝑎0.5a\leq 0.5italic_a ≤ 0.5 is a trivial case, always solved by a finite unary code,

𝒄u⁢(n)≜(0,10,110,…,1n-2⁢0,1n-1).≜superscript𝒄u𝑛010110…superscript1𝑛20superscript1𝑛1{\mbox{\boldmath$c$}}^{\mbox{\scriptsize u}}(n)\triangleq(0,10,110,\ldots,1^{n% -2}0,1^{n-1}).bold_italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) ≜ ( 0 , 10 , 110 , … , 1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 , 1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) .

This can be seen by applying the exponential combination rule (7) of the associated Huffman-like algorithm; at each step, the combined weight will be the lowest weight of the reduced problem, being strictly less than the higher of the two combined weights, thus leading to a unary code.

Campbell first proposed exponential utility functions for coding in [26, 27]. The optimal cost in both cases is quite close to entropy, indicating that better upper bounds might be possible. In looking for better bounds, recall first that the inequalities in (16) — like the use of the exponential Huffman algorithm — apply for both a∈(0.5,1)𝑎0.51a\in(0.5,1)italic_a ∈ ( 0.5 , 1 ) and a>1𝑎1a>1italic_a > 1. Improved bounds on the optimal solution for the a>1𝑎1a>1italic_a > 1 case are given in [21], but not in closed form or in terms of a single probability and entropy. Closed-form bounds for a related objective are given in [33]. However, the proof for the latter set of bounds is incorrect in that it uses the assumption that we will always have an exponential-average-optimal l1subscript𝑙1l_{1}italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT equal to 1111 if p1≥0.4subscript𝑝10.4p_{1}\geq 0.4italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0.4. We shortly disprove this assumption for a>1𝑎1a>1italic_a > 1, showing the need for modified entropy bounds. Before this, we derive bounds based on the results of the prior section.

V-C Exponential-average shortest codeword length

Techniques for finding Huffman coding bounds do not always translate readily to exponential generalizations because Rényi entropy’s very definition[39] involves a relaxation of a property used in finding bounds such as Gallager’s entropy bounds[3], namely

The penalty function Lasubscript𝐿𝑎L_{a}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT differs from the usual measure of expectation in an analogous fashion, and we cannot know the weight of a given subtree in the optimal code (merged item in the coding procedure) simply by knowing the sum probability of the items included. Theorem 3

V-C2 a>1𝑎1a>1italic_a > 1

Given a>1𝑎1a>1italic_a > 1 and p1<1subscript𝑝11p_{1}<1italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 1, we wish to show that a probability distribution always exists such that there is no optimal code with l1=1subscript𝑙11l_{1}=1italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1. We first show that, for the exponential penalties as for the traditional Huffman penalty, every optimal 𝒍𝒍lbold_italic_l can be obtained via the (modified) Huffman procedure. That is, if multiple length vectors are optimal, each optimal length vector can be obtained by the Huffman procedure as long as ties are broken in a certain manner.

Clearly the optimal code is obtained for n=2𝑛2n=2italic_n = 2. Let n′superscript𝑛′n^{\prime}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the smallest n𝑛nitalic_n for which there is an 𝒍𝒍lbold_italic_l that is optimal but cannot be obtained via the algorithm. Since 𝒍𝒍lbold_italic_l is optimal, consider the two smallest probabilities, pn′subscript𝑝superscript𝑛′p_{n^{\prime}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and pn′-1subscript𝑝superscript𝑛′1p_{n^{\prime}-1}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In this optimal code, two items having these probabilities (although not necessarily items n′-1superscript𝑛′1n^{\prime}-1italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 and n′superscript𝑛′n^{\prime}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) must have the longest codewords and must have the same codeword lengths. Were the latter not the case, the codeword of the more probable item could be exchanged with one of a less probable item, resulting in a better code. Were the former not the case, the longest codeword length could be decreased by one without violating the Kraft inequality, resulting in a better code. Either way, the code would no longer be optimal. Thus we can find two such smallest items with largest codewords (by breaking any ties properly), which, without loss of generality, can be considered siblings. Therefore the problem can be reduced to one of size n′-1superscript𝑛′1n^{\prime}-1italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 via the exponential Huffman algorithm. But since all problems of size n′-1superscript𝑛′1n^{\prime}-1italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 can be solved via the algorithm, this is a contradiction, and the Huffman algorithm can thus find any optimal code.

Note that this is not true for minimizing maximum pointwise redundancy, as the exchange argument no longer holds. This is why the sufficient condition of Section III was not verified using Huffman-like methods.
